bookTitle: St. Francis of Assisi: Passion, Poverty and the Man who Transformed the Catholic Church

questions.question: When was Francis' masculine vigor balanced by his tender emotions?
questions.correctAnswer: While he was admiring the serene nature landscapes after he had hiked into the ruggedness of the mountains
distractors: When he was caring for the lepers
When he was preaching to the crowds
When he was praying in the churches
When he was working to rebuild San Damiano
When he was meeting with the Pope

questions.question: What did Francis do when he hiked up the mountain to the crags and caves?
questions.correctAnswer: He would search out places to be alone and pray to God
distractors: He would preach to the birds and animals
He would fast for forty days
He would write his rule for the friars
He would perform penances
He would meet with other hermits

questions.question: Why were the mountains considered the seat of the gods in ancient times?
questions.correctAnswer: They were 'up high' and closer to the heavens
distractors: They were places where visions occurred
They were unreachable by ordinary people
They were where temples were built
They were believed to touch the sky
They were sacred to pagan religions

questions.question: What two dimensions does the cross have? What does Francis think of each dimension in relation to living the Christian life?
questions.correctAnswer: The cross has both a horizontal and vertical beam. Francis reflected that the vertical beam points up towards God like gazing at a mountaintop calling one to prayer and the horizontal beam reaches out towards the horizon and is the Christian call to serve others
distractors: The cross has height and width. The height represents reaching for heaven and the width represents embracing all people
The cross has wood and nails. The wood represents Christ's humanity and the nails represent his suffering
The cross has an upright and crossbeam. The upright is our relationship with God and the crossbeam is our relationship with the church
The cross has length and breadth. The length is eternal life and the breadth is God's universal love
The cross has form and substance. The form is doctrine and the substance is lived faith

questions.question: How did Francis reflect upon the mountaintop and the valley in relation to knowing God?
questions.correctAnswer: When praying, Francis focused on both God's power and majesty in connection with the mountaintop and also remembered how God humbled Himself to be with us in Jesus when returning to the valley
distractors: The mountaintop represented heaven and the valley represented earth
The mountaintop was for solitude and the valley was for service
The mountaintop showed God's glory and the valley showed human suffering
The mountaintop was the place of revelation and the valley was daily life
The mountaintop represented spiritual heights and the valley represented humble beginnings

questions.question: What did it mean that Francis' ministry would alternate between the mountains and the plains?
questions.correctAnswer: His ministry would be both prayer alone in the mountains and service to others and preaching the gospel in the cities
distractors: He would spend summers in the mountains and winters in the cities
He would retreat when discouraged and serve when encouraged
He would pray in the mountains and fast in the plains
He would teach in the mountains and heal in the cities
He would build churches in the mountains and monasteries in the plains

questions.question: How were Francis' hermitages physically different from traditional monasteries?
questions.correctAnswer: They were unpretentious natural structures immersed in the setting of nature, temporary and simple without decorations rather than places of permanency and strength made with thick walls and decorated with Christian art
distractors: They were smaller and held fewer people
They had no churches or chapels attached
They were built on mountaintops instead of valleys
They had no libraries or scriptoriums
They were made of wood instead of stone

questions.question: What did praying at the hermitages give Francis that was different from devoting oneself to prayer in a monastery?
questions.correctAnswer: Freedom to come to the hermitage and pray deeply and profoundly and then return to his call to preach and serve the poor unlike life in a monastery that required members to remain in the monastery for a life of prayer
distractors: Greater solitude without the distractions of community
More intense spiritual experiences through fasting
Direct connection with nature as God's creation
Ability to receive visions and revelations
Deeper contemplation without monastic obligations

questions.question: What concrete stories from the life of Christ did Francis meditate upon?
distractors: The baptism, temptation and transfiguration
The parables, miracles and teachings
The Last Supper, crucifixion and ascension
The incarnation, ministry and second coming
The birth, hidden life and public ministry

questions.question: Francis' prayer was focused on the imitation of Christ. Francis became more and more a channel of what?
distractors: God's justice and mercy
God's wisdom and power
God's peace and joy
God's healing and miracles
God's truth and light
